Posts.Content: Jan 25, 2010 02:55PM 2frogs1princess wrote: Hi Tara, If the kind of biopsy you will be having is a stereotactic biopsy, you will be lying on your stomach on a table. There is a hole in the table that your breast will go through. Under the table there is a mammogram machine that they will use to locate the calcifications. They will give you a local anesthetic which will burn a little. After that, you shouldn't feel any pain, maybe some pressure. The clip they were talking about is about the size of an ant, and no, it will not set off any alarms. It will cause you no problems. If your biopsy comes out benign, consider the clip your souvenier :) if the biopsy comes out as something that needs to be removed, then the surgeons use that as a marker to know what tissue to remove to ensure they remove the correct area. Hope this helps, and best of luck to you...
Posts.Title: ?'s about biopsy redspark3 redspark3

Posts.Content: Apr 15, 2009 03:09PM 2frogs1princess wrote: No need to worry! The breast surgeon will want to look at all your imaging whether or not something shows up. That is just good practice. Have you had any genetic counseling for your family history? You might want to look in to getting the BRCA 1 and BRCA 2 testing.
Posts.Title: radiologist gave me a disc of MRI gabbysmom gabbysmom

Posts.Content: Apr 6, 2009 01:13PM 2frogs1princess wrote: I waited two years. I felt exactly the same way as you.....tired of wondering if and when the other shoe would drop, AND wanted "a matching set" :o) I was 30 when I was diagnosed and had breastfed two children. I had one standing at attention and the other not paying attention! I had the BRCA testing done (no family hx but why does a 30 yr old get breast cancer?) and it was negative. My doctor supported my decision and I went with it. That was 1 and 1/2 years ago and not one minute have I regretted my decision. It was more surgery, but now I'm done with ALL of it! Good luck to you, it is a big decision to make, but you will make the right one. Take care.
Posts.Title: contralateral prophylactice mastectomy 2 years later ally2 mythreesons

Posts.Content: May 3, 2010 03:59PM 2frogs1princess wrote: Can you check the same area on the opposite breast to see if you feel a lump? It is possible that what you are feeling is the port of your implant. If so, you might be able to feel the same thing on the opposite breast. Still good to get it checked out though.

Posts.Title: just feeling all alone Kathyi6re desdemona222b

Posts.Content: Apr 6, 2009 03:51PM 2frogs1princess wrote: Kathy, my recommendation to you would be to have your general doc schedule and send an order for ultrasound guided biopsy of your breast to your breast center. You could have the biopsy done and results back before you even see the breast surgeon and then he would be able to have a plan ready for you when you go see him. Waiting is the worst part of it all and at least this way you could get something out of the way. JMO.
Posts.Title: just feeling all alone Kathyi6re desdemona222b

Posts.Content: Jan 13, 2009 06:12AM 2frogs1princess wrote: Hi there you two.....wanted to tell you both so sorry that you are going through this. I found my lump 1 month after I weaned my 15 month old son. My oldest was 4 1/2. It is not easy going through surgery, chemo, radiation etc when you have little ones but it definitely is do-able! I am now 3 1/2 years out of diagnosis and have an 8 month old little girl to boot! She was definitely a surprise to all as I was receiving hormone therapy when I got pregnant....definitely a little miracle. It is so good to see that you two found each other and it sounds like your treatment paths might be pretty similar.  Good luck to you both!

Posts.Content: Apr 6, 2009 05:00PM 2frogs1princess wrote: Dear OB/Gyn: Thank you for getting me in the next day when I told you I found a lump. Thank you for taking me seriously and sending me for a mammogram and ultrasound at age 30 to check it out. But please, in the future, send your patients to a breast surgeon, not a general surgeon for consultation. Had I gone to a breast surgeon, maybe they would of actually removed the lump instead of tissue just lateral to it. Then they would have know I had invasive cancer in addition to the DCIS he found. Dear Onc and Onc NP:  You two are absolutely wonderful!!!
